elements.content: The 1/2V2O5−H2C2O4/H3PO4/NH4OH system was investigated using hydrothermal techniques. Four new phases, (NH4)VOPO4·1.5H2O (1), (NH4)0.5VOPO4·1.5H2O (2), (NH4)2[VO(H2O)3]2[VO(H2O)][VO(PO4)2]2·3H2O (3), and (NH4)2[VO(HPO4)]2(C2O4)·H2O (4), have been prepared and structurally characterized. Compounds 1 and 2 have layered structures closely related to VOPO4·2H2O and A0.5VOPO4·yH2O (A = mono- or divalent metals), whereas 3 has a 3D open-framework structure. Compound 4 has a layered structure and contains both oxalate and phosphate anions coordinated to vanadium cations. Crystal data:  (NH4)VOPO4·1.5H2O, tetragonal (I), space group I4/mmm (No. 139), a = 6.3160(5) Å, c = 13.540(2) Å, Z = 4; (NH4)0.5VOPO4·1.5H2O, monoclinic, space group P21/m (No. 11), a = 6.9669(6) Å, b = 17.663(2) Å, c = 8.9304(8) Å, β = 105.347(1)°, Z = 8; (NH4)2[VO(H2O)3]2[VO(H2O)][VO(PO4)2]2·3H2O, triclinic, space group P1̄ (No. 2), a = 10.2523(9) Å, b = 12.263(1) Å, c = 12.362(1) Å, α = 69.041(2)°, β = 65.653(2)°, γ = 87.789(2)°, Z = 2; (NH4)2[VO(HPO4)]2(C2O4)·5H2O, monoclinic (C), space group C2/m (No. 12), a = 17.735(2) Å, b = 6.4180(6) Å, c = 22.839(2) Å, β = 102.017(2)°, Z = 6.

elements.content: The 1/2V2O5−H2C2O4/H3PO4/NH4OH system was investigated using hydrothermal syntheses. The oxalic acid in the syntheses plays the role of a reducing agent but in some regions of reactant composition also acts as a ligand. As a result of this study, reaction conditions for the synthesis of two layered vanadium phosphates, (NH4)VOPO4·1.5H2O (1) and (NH4)0.5VOPO4·1.5H2O (2), with structures closely related to VOPO4·2H2O have been established. A new framework structure, (NH4)2[VO(H2O)3]2[VO(H2O)][VO(PO4)2]2·3H2O (3), and a vanadium oxalato−phosphate, (NH4)2[VO(HPO4)]2(C2O4)·5H2O (4), have been obtained in the same reaction system.

elements.content: Vanadium phosphates and organophosphonates are a large class of compounds that has been studied in detail. Specific compounds find application in oxidation catalysis, and others have potential uses as solid sorbents and ion exchangers. The layered compound VOPO4·2H2O is one of the best known examples, and many compounds have been synthesized with closely related structures. For example, the mixed-valence A x VOPO4·yH2O phases were synthesized by redox intercalation reactions of VOPO4·2H2O. Several other layered mixed-valence vanadium phosphate hydrates A0.5VOPO4·xH2O (A = Na, x = 2; A = K, x = 1.5) and divalent metal incorporated compounds A0.5VOPO4·2H2O (A = Ca, Ba, Sr, Co, Ni, Cu, Pb) were subsequently prepared hydrothermally.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Vanadium phosphates and organophosphonates are a large class of compounds that has been studied in detail. Specific compounds find application in oxidation catalysis, and others have potential uses as solid sorbents and ion exchangers. The layered compound VOPO4⋅2H2O is one of the best known examples, and many compounds have been synthesized with closely related structures. For example, the mixed-valence A x VOPO4⋅yH2O phases were synthesized by redox intercalation reactions of VOPO4⋅2H2O. Several other layered mixed-valence vanadium phosphate hydrates A0.5VOPO4⋅xH2O (A = Na, x = 2; A = K, x = 1.5) and divalent metal incorporated compounds A0.5VOPO4⋅2H2O (A = Ca, Ba, Sr, Co, Ni, Cu, Pb) were subsequently prepared hydrothermally.

elements.content: In a recent paper, the effect of conditions on the synthesis of vanadium(IV) phosphate phases from solution was described. Oxalic acid was used as the reducing agent to prepare a V(IV) solution from V(V) starting materials. From this solution a series of V(IV) phosphate hydrates were isolated by varying crystallization conditions. Oxalate anions may also directly coordinate transition metals, and several transition metal (Mn, In, Ga, Al, and Fe) systems have been synthesized in which the transition metal cations are coordinated by both phosphate and oxalate anions. Most recently an example of a V(IV) linear chain oxalato−phosphate, (C4H12N2)[VO(C2O4)HPO4], was reported. The structure of this compound is related to that of VOHPO4·4H2O. These oxalato−phosphates are limited in number but show several modes of oxalate binding and different framework connectivities.

Oxalate anions may also directly coordinate transition metals, and several transition metal (Mn, In, Ga, Al, and Fe) systems have been synthesized in which the transition metal cations are coordinated by both phosphate and oxalate anions. Most recently an example of a V(IV) linear chain oxalato-phosphate, (C4H12N2)[VO(C2O4)HPO4], was reported. The structure of this compound is related to that of VOHPO4⋅4H2O. These oxalato-phosphates are limited in number but show several modes of oxalate binding and different framework connectivities.

elements.content: In this paper, we report the results of a systematic study of reactions of V2O5 in the H2C2O4/H3PO4/NH4OH system using hydrothermal syntheses. The oxalic acid in the syntheses plays the role of a reducing agent but in some regions of reactant composition also acts as a ligand. As a result of this study, reaction conditions for the synthesis of two layered vanadium phosphates, (NH4)VOPO4·1.5H2O (1) and (NH4)0.5VOPO4·1.5H2O (2), with structures closely related to VOPO4·2H2O were established. Compound 1 was previously obtained in microcrystalline form by electrochemical hydrothermal synthesis. A new framework structure, (NH4)2[VO(H2O)3]2[VO(H2O)][VO(PO4)2]2·3H2O (3), and a vanadium oxalato−phosphate, (NH4)2[VO(HPO4)]2(C2O4)·5H2O (4), were obtained in the same reaction system. Single crystals were obtained, and the structures of 1 − 4 were determined by X-ray diffraction.

Compound 1 was previously obtained in microcrystalline form by electrochemical hydrothermal synthesis. A new framework structure, (NH4)2[VO(H2O)3]2[VO(H2O)][VO(PO4)2]2⋅3H2O (3), and a vanadium oxalato-phosphate, (NH4)2[VO(HPO4)]2(C2O4)⋅5H2O (4), were obtained in the same reaction system. Single crystals were obtained, and the structures of 1 - 4 were determined by X-ray diffraction.

elements.content: Synthesis. The 1/2V2O5−H2C2O4/H3PO4/NH4OH system was investigated as function of the initial compositions of the reactants in a systematic way. Hydrothermal reactions were carried out in 23-mL capacity Teflon-lined stainless steel Parr hydrothermal reaction vessels at 140 °C for 3 days. The solid products were recovered by vacuum filtration and washed with water. All the phases are stable in air and water. The phases present in a series of reactions with different initial reactant compositions are shown in Figure .
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

 Synthesis. The 1/2V2O5-H2C2O4/H3PO4/NH4OH system was investigated as function of the initial compositions of the reactants in a systematic way. Hydrothermal reactions were carried out in 23-mL capacity Teflon-lined stainless steel Parr hydrothermal reaction vessels at 140 °C for 3 days. The solid products were recovered by vacuum filtration and washed with water. All the phases are stable in air and water. The phases present in a series of reactions with different initial reactant compositions are shown in Figure .

elements.content: Green polyhedral crystals of (NH4)(VOPO4)·1.5H2O (1) were prepared from the reaction of 0.0909 g of V2O5 (0.5 mmol), 0.0900 g of H2C2O4 (1 mmol), 0.21 mL of H3PO4 (3 mmol; 85 wt % solution in H2O), 0.26 mL of NH4OH (2 mmol; 29.6 wt % aqueous solution), and 3 mL of water. The initial solution pH was 2.28. Product recovery (87% yield based on V) gave (NH4)(VOPO4)·1.5H2O single crystals together with a small quantity of unidentified black material. The pH after the reaction was 5.73. (NH4)(VOPO4)·1.5H2O could not be synthesized by using a stoichiometric reaction with V:P:NH4 = 1:1:1. An unidentified pale greenish gray microcrystalline phase was formed instead.

elements.content: Dark green platy crystals of (NH4)0.5(VOPO4)·1.5H2O (2) form over a narrow range of conditions (Figure ). The product was accompanied by either 3 or red crystals of NH4VOPO4. The best crystals of 2 were formed in 74% yield from the reaction of 0.0454 g of V2O5 (0.25 mmol), 0.0450 g of H2C2O4 (0.5 mmol), 0.21 mL of H3PO4 (3 mmol; 85 wt % solution in H2O), 0.13 mL of NH4OH (1 mmol; 29.6 wt % aqueous solution), and 3 mL of water. The pH values before and after reaction were 1.93 and 2.10, respectively. In 2 the degree of vanadium reduction (1VV + 1VIV) is less than in 1 (all V(IV)).

elements.content: (NH4)2[VO(H2O)3]2[VO(H2O)][VO(PO4)2]2·3H2O (3) was obtained over a wide range of conditions (Figure ). The best crystals of 3 were prepared from the reaction of 0.1364 g of V2O5 (0.75 mmol), 0.1350 g of H2C2O4 (1.5 mmol), 0.21 mL of H3PO4 (3 mmol; 85 wt % solution in H2O), 0.065 mL of NH4OH (0.5 mmol; 29.6 wt % aqueous solution), and 3 mL of water. Blue platy crystals (31% yield based on V) were obtained as a single phase. The compound 3 is obtained in the pH range 1.87−5.23. Reactions at lower pH give higher yields, and a single-phase product is formed at very low pH 1.87.

elements.content: The best crystals of (NH4)2[VO(HPO4)]2(C2O4)·5H2O (4) were synthesized as plates in 96% yield from the reaction of 0.0909 g of V2O5 (0.5 mmol), 0.0900 g of H2C2O4 (1 mmol), 0.17 mL of H3PO4 (2.5 mmol; 85 wt % solution in H2O), 0.13 mL of NH4OH (1 mmol; 29.6 wt % aqueous solution), and 3 mL of water. The solution pH values before and after the reaction were 1.89 and 3.29, respectively. In all three of the reactions shown in Figure , 4 was always accompanied by 3 as a minority phase. Compound 4 is obtained only in the pH range 3.3−3.8.

elements.content: Characterization. Infrared spectra were recorded on a Mattson FTIR 5000 spectrometer within the range 400−4000 cm-1 using the KBr pellet method. Thermogravimetric analyses were carried out in air at a heating rate of 2 °C/min, using a high-resolution TGA 2950 thermogravimetric analyzer (TA Instruments). Magnetic measurements were made with an Oxford Instruments vibrating sample magnetometer in the temperature range 4 < T (K) < 290 with an applied magnetic field of 1 T.

Thermogravimetric analyses were carried out in air at a heating rate of 2 °C/min, using a high-resolution TGA 2950 thermogravimetric analyzer (TA Instruments). Magnetic measurements were made with an Oxford Instruments vibrating sample magnetometer in the temperature range 4 < T (K) < 290 with an applied magnetic field of 1 T.

elements.content: Crystal Structures. The crystal structures of 1−4 were determined by single-crystal X-ray diffraction methods. Preliminary examination and data collection were performed on a SMART platform diffractometer equipped with a 1K CCD area detector using graphite-monochromatized Mo Kα radiation at room temperature. A hemisphere of data (1271 frames at 5 cm detector distance) was collected using a narrow-frame method with scan widths of 0.30° in ω and an exposure time of 30 s/frame. The first 50 frames were remeasured at the end of data collection to monitor instrument and crystal stability, and the maximum correction applied on the intensities was <1%. The data were integrated using the Siemens SAINT program, with the intensities corrected for the Lorentz factor, polarization, air absorption, and absorption due to variation in the path length through the detector faceplate. The program SADABS was used for the absorption correction. Additional crystallographic details for 1−4 are given in Table . In all cases satisfactory refinements were obtained with the highest symmetry centrosymmetric space groups consistent with the systematic absence conditions.

The reactions shown in the mixture diagram (Figure ) result in the formation of six distinct compounds. Single crystals of three new hydrated ammonium vanadium phosphates, one ammonium vanadium oxalato−phosphate, and two known phases (NH4)VOPO4 26 and (NH4)2(VO)(V1 - x P1+ x O7) were synthesized. elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

 Synthesis. The 1/2V2O5-H2C2O4/H3PO4/NH4OH system was studied as a function of the initial compositions. The reactions shown in the mixture diagram (Figure ) result in the formation of six distinct compounds. Single crystals of three new hydrated ammonium vanadium phosphates, one ammonium vanadium oxalato-phosphate, and two known phases (NH4)VOPO4 26 and (NH4)2(VO)(V1 -  x P1+  x O7) were synthesized. The compound NH4VOPO4⋅H2O, which has a structure related to that of VO(HPO4)⋅4H2O, was not observed under the conditions shown in Figure . The figure is divided into three regions, A, B, and C, that qualitatively represent composition regions where different compound types are formed.

elements.content: All of the compounds that were identified and isolated as single crystals were prepared in the H3PO4-rich region of the mixture diagram (regions B and C). Only poorly crystalline phases or gels were formed in the H2C2O4- and NH4OH-rich regions (3.4 ≤ pH ≤ 7.3) (region A). These phases could not be identified, but infrared measurements indicated that they did not contain oxalate anions.
elements.clean_text: All of the compounds that were identified and isolated as single crystals were prepared in the H3PO4-rich region of the mixture diagram (regions B and C). Only poorly crystalline phases or gels were formed in the H2C2O4- and NH4OH-rich regions (3.4 ≤ pH ≤ 7.3) (region A). These phases could not be identified, but infrared measurements indicated that they did not contain oxalate anions.

elements.content: In region B, the predominant phase observed is 3. This compound forms over a wide range of reactant compositions with 1.8 ≤ pH ≤ 5.2 and contains only V(IV). Compound 4, the only phase synthesized that contains oxalate anions, was also isolated in region B. 4 is formed together with 3 in a narrow range of composition and only in a very narrow pH range (3.3 ≤ pH ≤ 3.8).
elements.clean_text: In region B, the predominant phase observed is 3. This compound forms over a wide range of reactant compositions with 1.8 ≤ pH ≤ 5.2 and contains only V(IV). Compound 4, the only phase synthesized that contains oxalate anions, was also isolated in region B. 4 is formed together with 3 in a narrow range of composition and only in a very narrow pH range (3.3 ≤ pH ≤ 3.8).

elements.content: Four compounds were formed in region C:  NH4VOPO4·1.5H2O (1); (NH4)0.5(VOPO4)·1.5H2O (2); and two known phases, NH4VOPO4 26 and (NH4)2(VO)(V1 - x P1+ x O7). Phase 1 and NH4VOPO4 contain V(IV) only whereas 2 and (NH4)2(VO)(V1 - x P1+ x O7) are mixed-valence (IV and V) compounds. Lowering the oxalate concentration in the solution favors the formation of V(V)-containing phases and gives rise to the boundary between regions B and C.
elements.clean_text: Four compounds were formed in region C: NH4VOPO4⋅1.5H2O (1); (NH4)0.5(VOPO4)⋅1.5H2O (2); and two known phases, NH4VOPO4 26 and (NH4)2(VO)(V1 -  x P1+  x O7). Phase 1 and NH4VOPO4 contain V(IV) only whereas 2 and (NH4)2(VO)(V1 -  x P1+  x O7) are mixed-valence (IV and V) compounds. Lowering the oxalate concentration in the solution favors the formation of V(V)-containing phases and gives rise to the boundary between regions B and C.

elements.content: Characterization. The IR spectra of 1−4 are shown in Figure . Vibration modes for P−O, V−O, and VO are observed at 1121, 1005, 679, 540, 438 cm-1, 1; 1150, 1063, 1021, 959, 895, 681, 569, 531 cm-1, 2; 1099, 1049, 1029, 982, 887, 615, 561 cm-1, 3; 1117, 1076, 993, 812, 648, 525, 486 cm-1, 4. Strong absorption bands for N−H and O−H bending and stretching vibrations are observed at 3364, 3061, 1641, 1491, 1431 cm-1, 1; 3530, 3144, 1624, 1417, 1433 cm-1, 2; 3502, 3144, 1630, 1409, 1437 cm-1, 3; 3445, 3148, 1402 cm-1, 4. Additional bands due to C−O vibrations for 4 occur at 1674, 1356, 1316, 902 cm-1.

elements.content: Thermogravimetric analysis of 2 shows that the evolution of NH3 and water molecules occurs from room temperature to ∼470 °C, and that the oxidation of V4+ to V5+ is complete at ∼770 °C. Assuming that the residue corresponds to 1/2V2O5 and 1/2P2O5, then the observed weight loss (18.32%) is in good agreement with the calculated value (18.20%) for the composition (NH4)0.5[VOPO4]·1.5H2O. For 3 the evolution of NH3 and water molecules from the structure also is observed to occur below ∼470 °C in several steps. Assuming that the glassy residue corresponds to 5/2V2O5 and 2P2O5, the overall observed weight loss (20.80%) is in good agreement with the value calculated for the composition (NH4)2[VO(H2O)3]2[VO(H2O)][VO(PO4)2]2·3H2O (20.65%). For 4 the evolution of crystal water occurs below 200 °C, and evolution of NH3 and H2O and carbon oxides was observed between ∼200 °C and 350 °C (weight loss, calcd 23.45%, exptl 23.96%). The evolution of water molecules from the structure and the oxidation of V4+ to V5+ is complete near 770 °C. Thermogravimetric analysis data were previously reported for 1 and gave a composition NH4VOPO4·1.4H2O.

elements.content: Magnetic susceptibility data for 2 revealed paramagnetic behavior over the temperature range 4.5−250 K. The data were modeled by the Curie−Weiss function χm = χ0 + C m/(T − θ), χ0 = −2.09 × 10-4 emu/mol, C m = 0.3812 emu K/mol, and θ = −6.5 K. The calculated effective magnetic moment μeff = 1.75 μB is in good agreement with the expected value of 1.73 μB, assuming that one-half of the vanadium atoms in the formulas (NH4)[VOPO4]2·3H2O are present as V(IV). Magnetic susceptibility data for 3 also revealed paramagnetic behavior over the temperature range 4.0−288 K. The data were fitted by the Curie equation:  χm = χ0 + C m/T, χ0 = −4.45 × 10-4 emu/mol, and C m = 1.869 emu K/mol. The calculated effective magnetic moment μeff = 3.867 μB is in agreement with the expected value of 3.87 μB, assuming that all five vanadium atoms in the (NH4)2[VO(H2O)3]2[VO(H2O)][VO(PO4)2]2·3H2O are present as V(IV). The magnetic measurements for 4 also indicated a V4+ oxidation state with χ0 = −7.0 × 10-5 emu/mol, C m = 0.3692 emu K/mol, θ = −4.5 K, and μeff = 1.72 μB.

elements.content: Crystal Structures. The structure of 1 consists of VOPO4 layers of VO5 square pyramids and PO4 tetrahedra with NH4 + cations and water molecules between the layers (Figures and ). One crystallographically unique V atom has a short vanadium oxygen (vanadyl) bond VO (1.578(5) Å) and four equivalent equatorial V−O bonds (2.000(2) Å). The four equatorial oxygen atoms are shared with four phosphate tetrahedra, and each tetrahedron is connected to four distorted octahedra to make up the layers. The NH4 + cations and water molecules occupy sites between the layers. They are indistinguishable because they are disordered over the one crystallographically distinct atom site between the layers. The BVS value calculated for V is 3.98, in good agreement with the expected value of 4.00 for V(IV).

elements.content: The structure of 2 consists of VOPO4·H2O layers of VO6 distorted octahedra and PO4 tetrahedra and interlayer NH4 + cations and water molecules (Figures and ). The four equatorial oxygen atoms in each VO6 octahedron are shared with four PO4 tetrahedra. One of the axial V−O bonds in each octahedron is a vanadyl group VO (1.61(1) Å, V(1); 1.57(1) Å, V(2); 1.582(6) Å, V(3)). The long V−O bonds (2.32(1) Å, V(1); 2.310(9) Å, V(2); 2.372(7) Å, V(3)) to coordinated water molecules are trans to the short VO bonds. The BVS calculation gives values of 3.92, 5.26, and 4.54 for V(1), V(2), and V(3), respectively, indicating oxidation states of 4.00 for V(1), 5.00 for V(2), and an average of 4.5 for V(3). One interlayer site is fully occupied and assigned to the NH4 + cation. The NH4 + cation H-bonds with seven neighboring oxygen atoms in the layers (Figure ). The water molecules between the layers are disordered.

elements.content: The structures of 1 and 2 are closely related to the tetragonal layer structure of VOPO4·2H2O, and other layered mixed-valence vanadium phosphate hydrates containing interlayer metal cations6-13 and (piperazineH2)VOPO4. The structures of 1 and 2 may be thought of as arising from the insertion of NH4 + into VOPO4·2H2O with full (1) or partial (2) reduction of V5+ to V4+. The modifications to the local coordination of V atoms and to the stacking arrangement of the vanadium phosphate layers relative to parent compound that occur are similar to those observed in compounds containing interlayer monovalent or divalent cations. The local geometry of V4+ in 1, NH4VOPO4·H2O, (piperazineH2)VOPO4, and M(VOPO4)2·4H2O (M = Co, Ni)9-13 is square pyramidal, whereas in 2, VOPO4·2H2O, and M0.5VOPO4·nH2O (A = Ca, Sr, Ba, Cu, Pb, Na, K)8-13 distorted octahedra are found.
elements.clean_text: The structures of 1 and 2 are closely related to the tetragonal layer structure of VOPO4⋅2H2O, and other layered mixed-valence vanadium phosphate hydrates containing interlayer metal cations6-13 and (piperazineH2)VOPO4. The structures of 1 and 2 may be thought of as arising from the insertion of NH4 + into VOPO4⋅2H2O with full (1) or partial (2) reduction of V5+ to V4+. The modifications to the local coordination of V atoms and to the stacking arrangement of the vanadium phosphate layers relative to parent compound that occur are similar to those observed in compounds containing interlayer monovalent or divalent cations. The local geometry of V4+ in 1, NH4VOPO4⋅H2O, (piperazineH2)VOPO4, and M(VOPO4)2⋅4H2O (M = Co, Ni)9-13 is square pyramidal, whereas in 2, VOPO4⋅2H2O, and M0.5VOPO4⋅nH2O (A = Ca, Sr, Ba, Cu, Pb, Na, K)8-13 distorted octahedra are found.

elements.content: In 2, the presence of four inequivalent equatorial V−O bonds leads to puckered VOPO4·H2O layers (Figure ). The puckering isolates the interlayer solvent molecules into clusters surrounded by NH4 + cations. The arrangement is reminiscent of domains in staged intercalation compounds. The interlayer separations for 1 and 2 are 6.770 and 6.967 Å, respectively, which are shorter than that of VOPO4·2H2O (7.403 Å) and longer than those of K (6.38 Å), Na (6.53 Å), Ca(6.30 Å), Ba (6.39 Å), Sr (6.32 Å), Cu (6.42 Å), and Pb (6.34 Å) compounds. The interlayer separation for 1 is similar to the values found for the Co (6.714 Å) and Ni (6.667 Å) compounds which have the same stacking arrangement as 1. The average in plane dimensions of the layers are similar with 6.316 Å (a), 6.280 Å [(b/4)2 + (c/2)2]1/2, and 6.215 Å (a) for 1, 2, and VOPO4·2H2O, respectively.

elements.content: In 3, the [VO(H2O)3]2[VO(H2O)][VO(PO4)2]2 2- framework is built up from six crystallographically distinct VO6 distorted octahedra and PO4 tetrahedra. The V(1)O6 octahedra contain one short VO bond, one long V−OH2 bond trans to the VO bond, and four equatorial V−O bonds intermediate in length. The equatorial oxygen atoms are shared with phosphate groups. The V(2)O6 and V(3)O6 octahedra also contain one short VO bond and one long trans V−OH2 bond but differ from V(1)O6 in that the coordination in the equatorial plain is completed by two oxygen atoms from phosphate groups and two additional water molecules. The BVSs are 4.19, 4.01, and 4.10 for V(1), V(2), and V(3), respectively, in agreement with an oxidation state of V(IV).

The equatorial oxygen atoms are shared with phosphate groups. The V(2)O6 and V(3)O6 octahedra also contain one short VO bond and one long trans V-OH2 bond but differ from V(1)O6 in that the coordination in the equatorial plain is completed by two oxygen atoms from phosphate groups and two additional water molecules. elements.content: The remaining distorted VO6 octahedra (V(4), V(5), and V(6)) share trans vertexes to form the −VO−VO− backbone of an infinite chain in the sequence V(4)−V(6)−V(5)−V(6)−V(4) (Figure ). The vanadium atom positions are disordered about the center of each octahedron most likely reflecting random −VO−VO− orientations of different chains. BVS calculations give values of 3.94, 4.07, and 3.98 for V(4), V(5), and V(6), respectively. Adjacent VO6 octahedra are bridged by two phosphate tetrahedra, sharing two corners of each tetrahedron to give an overall chain composition of VO(PO4)2. This chain is closely related to the one found in (NH4)2VO(HPO4)2·H2O and in a number of other hydrogen phosphate phases. Each chain is connected to an adjacent chain through the V(1)O5H2O units to form a layer (Figure ), and the layers are connected by the V(2,3)O3(H2O)3 octahedra (Figure ) to form a three- dimensional framework with the composition [VO(H2O)3]2[VO(H2O)][VO(PO4)2]2 2-. Two NH4 + cations and three water molecules occupy the positions (N1−5) in the channels along the [111] direction (Figure ).
elements.clean_text: The remaining distorted VO6 octahedra (V(4), V(5), and V(6)) share trans vertexes to form the -VO-VO- backbone of an infinite chain in the sequence V(4)-V(6)-V(5)-V(6)-V(4) (Figure ). The vanadium atom positions are disordered about the center of each octahedron most likely reflecting random -VO-VO- orientations of different chains. BVS calculations give values of 3.94, 4.07, and 3.98 for V(4), V(5), and V(6), respectively. Adjacent VO6 octahedra are bridged by two phosphate tetrahedra, sharing two corners of each tetrahedron to give an overall chain composition of VO(PO4)2. This chain is closely related to the one found in (NH4)2VO(HPO4)2⋅H2O and in a number of other hydrogen phosphate phases. Each chain is connected to an adjacent chain through the V(1)O5H2O units to form a layer (Figure ), and the layers are connected by the V(2,3)O3(H2O)3 octahedra (Figure ) to form a three- dimensional framework with the composition [VO(H2O)3]2[VO(H2O)][VO(PO4)2]2 2-. Two NH4 + cations and three water molecules occupy the positions (N1-5) in the channels along the [111] direction (Figure ).

elements.content: 3 and (C4H12N2)[(VO)4(H2O)4(HPO4)2(PO4)2] have similar framework structures both containing VO(PO4)2 chains connected to VO(H2O) n through the phosphate oxygen atoms. The structures differ in that 3 has no P−OH groups and contains a VO(H2O) n octahedron with n = 1 in addition to the n = 3 type found in both structures.

elements.content: In the structure of 4, the V atoms are coordinated by six oxygen atoms to form distorted octahedra. Three of the oxygen atoms are shared as common corners with three PO3OH groups with typical distances ranging from 1.984(7) to 2.007(5) Å for V(1), 1.973(7) to 2.017(5) Å for V(2), and 1.994(8) to 1.999(5) Å for V(3). Each of the remaining two oxygen atoms is shared with a C2O4 group with longer V−O distances of 2.091(6) and 2.297(7) Å, 2.074(8) and 2.284(8) Å, and 2.066(7) and 2.321(7) Å for V(1), V(2), and V(3), respectively. The last oxygen atom forms a vanadyl VO group with a short bond distance (1.609(7) Å, V(1); 1.584(8) Å, V(2); 1.576(8) Å, V(3)). The local coordination of the V atoms is shown in Figure . Pairs of vanadium−oxygen octahedra are linked together by a bridging C2O4 group in [V2C2O12] dimers. Three of the oxygen atoms of the PO4 groups are shared with the vanadium atoms. The fourth oxygen atom is terminal with long P−O distances of 1.594(7), 1.578(8), and 1.597(9) Å for V(1), V(2), and V(3), respectively, indicating P−OH groups. The bonding between the [V2C2O12] dimers and PO4 groups results in the layers with composition [VO(HPO4)2]2(C2O4)2- shown in Figure . Four VO6, two PO4, and two oxalate units form eight-member rings defined by the positions of O(7)−O(9) (5.208 Å) and C(2)/(1)−C(2)/(1) (6.418 Å) and by O(16)−O(16) (5.195 Å) and C(3)−C(3) (6.418 Å) (Figure ). The BVS values calculated for V(1), V(2), and V(3) are 3.97, 4.10, and 4.14, respectively, in agreement with the expected value of 4.00 for V(IV). There are two crystallographically unique [VO(HPO4)]2(C2O4) layers in the structure. The NH4 +/H2O species are located in the space between the [(VO(HPO4))2(C2O4)]2- layers (Figure ). An extended network of hydrogen bonds between the oxygen atoms completes the structure in three dimensions.

elements.content: The layer structure of 4 is related to that of the chain structure of (C4H12N2)[VO(HPO4)(C2O4)] as shown in Figure . Both structures contain double [VO(HPO4)]2 chains in which the terminal P−OH groups point in opposite directions alternating up and down along the direction of the chain (Figure ). Tsai et al. noted the structural relationship between the vanadium phosphate chains in the oxalate compound and a similar double VO(HPO4) chain found in the VO(HPO4)·4H2O24 structure. In the latter, two water molecules occupy the coordination positions of the oxalate anion. The structural analogy can be further extended by noting the relationship between (NH4)2[VO(HPO4)]2(C2O4)·5H2O and VO(HPO4)·1/2H2O and VOSeO3·H2O.

In the latter, two water molecules occupy the coordination positions of the oxalate anion. The structural analogy can be further extended by noting the relationship between (NH4)2[VO(HPO4)]2(C2O4)⋅5H2O and VO(HPO4)⋅1/2H2O and VOSeO3⋅H2O.

elements.content: The structure of 4 is related also to the structures of some other metal oxalato−phosphates. For example, in the structure of [C4H12N2][In2(C2O4)(HPO4)3]·H2O, similar [In2(C2O4)(HPO4)2] layers are connected together by bridging HPO4 groups as observed in N2C2H10(VO)2(PO4)2H2PO4 and other related compounds. In contrast, although [C2H10N2]2.5[Al4H(HPO4)4(H2PO4)(C2O4)4]17 contains bridging phosphate groups, the structure is more closely related to that of (C4H12N2)[VO(HPO4)(C2O4)].

cln_elements.content:
Green polyhedral crystals of (NH4)(VOPO4)·1.5H2O (1) were prepared from the reaction of 0.0909 g of V2O5 (0.5 mmol), 0.0900 g of H2C2O4 (1 mmol), 0.21 mL of H3PO4 (3 mmol; 85 wt % solution in H2O), 0.26 mL of NH4OH (2 mmol; 29.6 wt % aqueous solution), and 3 mL of water. The initial solution pH was 2.28. Product recovery (87% yield based on V) gave (NH4)(VOPO4)·1.5H2O single crystals together with a small quantity of unidentified black material. The pH after the reaction was 5.73. (NH4)(VOPO4)·1.5H2O could not be synthesized by using a stoichiometric reaction with V:P:NH4 = 1:1:1. An unidentified pale greenish gray microcrystalline phase was formed instead.

Dark green platy crystals of (NH4)0.5(VOPO4)·1.5H2O (2) form over a narrow range of conditions (Figure ). The product was accompanied by either 3 or red crystals of NH4VOPO4. The best crystals of 2 were formed in 74% yield from the reaction of 0.0454 g of V2O5 (0.25 mmol), 0.0450 g of H2C2O4 (0.5 mmol), 0.21 mL of H3PO4 (3 mmol; 85 wt % solution in H2O), 0.13 mL of NH4OH (1 mmol; 29.6 wt % aqueous solution), and 3 mL of water. The pH values before and after reaction were 1.93 and 2.10, respectively. In 2 the degree of vanadium reduction (1VV + 1VIV) is less than in 1 (all V(IV)).

(NH4)2[VO(H2O)3]2[VO(H2O)][VO(PO4)2]2·3H2O (3) was obtained over a wide range of conditions (Figure ). The best crystals of 3 were prepared from the reaction of 0.1364 g of V2O5 (0.75 mmol), 0.1350 g of H2C2O4 (1.5 mmol), 0.21 mL of H3PO4 (3 mmol; 85 wt % solution in H2O), 0.065 mL of NH4OH (0.5 mmol; 29.6 wt % aqueous solution), and 3 mL of water. Blue platy crystals (31% yield based on V) were obtained as a single phase. The compound 3 is obtained in the pH range 1.87−5.23. Reactions at lower pH give higher yields, and a single-phase product is formed at very low pH 1.87.

The best crystals of (NH4)2[VO(HPO4)]2(C2O4)·5H2O (4) were synthesized as plates in 96% yield from the reaction of 0.0909 g of V2O5 (0.5 mmol), 0.0900 g of H2C2O4 (1 mmol), 0.17 mL of H3PO4 (2.5 mmol; 85 wt % solution in H2O), 0.13 mL of NH4OH (1 mmol; 29.6 wt % aqueous solution), and 3 mL of water. The solution pH values before and after the reaction were 1.89 and 3.29, respectively. In all three of the reactions shown in Figure , 4 was always accompanied by 3 as a minority phase. Compound 4 is obtained only in the pH range 3.3−3.8.

metadata.title:
A Hydrothermal Investigation of the 1/2V2O5−H2C2O4/H3PO4/NH4OH System:  Synthesis
and Structures of (NH4)VOPO4·1.5H2O, (NH4)0.5VOPO4·1.5H2O,
(NH4)2[VO(H2O)3]2[VO(H2O)][VO(PO4)2]2·3H2O, and (NH4)2[VO(HPO4)]2(C2O4)·5H2O
